docs.abstract: Beijing's skies are so murky and polluted authorities are considering emergency measures during Olympic Games beyond traffic restrictions and factory shutdowns that, so far, have failed to clear air; photo (M)

headline.main: In Beijing, Blue Skies Prove Hard To Achieve

docs.snippet: Less than two weeks before the Olympics, Beijing's skies are so murky and polluted that the authorities are considering emergency measures during the Games beyond the traffic restrictions and factory shutdowns that, so far, have failed to clear the a
docs.lead_paragraph: Less than two weeks before the Olympics, Beijing's skies are so murky and polluted that the authorities are considering emergency measures during the Games beyond the traffic restrictions and factory shutdowns that, so far, have failed to clear the air, state media reported on Monday. For the past five days, Beijing has been a soupy caldron of humid, gray skies. Local pollution ratings have exceeded the national standard for acceptable air since last Thursday, despite a temporary air pollution control plan that began on July 20.

headline.main: Before Guests, Beijing Hides Some Messes

docs.snippet: Some businesses and residents will spend the Olympics behind walls erected to keep their property out of sight.
docs.lead_paragraph: Tourists leaving the west gate of the Temple of Heaven next month will probably not notice Song Wei's home across the street. Nor are spectators along the Olympic marathon route likely to stop by Sun Ruonan's restaurant nearby. Mr. Song and Ms. Sun live along Beijing's central axis in neighborhoods that have been gutted to make the city look clean and orderly for the Olympics. Both have held on despite pressure to move. They will spend the Olympics behind walls or screens erected to keep their property out of public view.

docs.abstract: Zagat publishes restaurant and hotel guide for Hong Kong, Shanghai and Beijing in advance of summer Olympic games; drawing (M)

headline.main: A Triple Play for the Olympics

docs.news_desk: Dining In, Dining Out / Style Desk
docs.snippet: A slender new Zagat guide covers 618 restaurants and 106 hotels in Hong Kong, Shanghai and Beijing.
docs.section_name: Travel; Dining and Wine; Style; Books
docs.lead_paragraph: If you're traveling to China this summer for the Olympics, you might want to take the slender new Zagat guide to 618 restaurants and 106 hotels in Hong Kong, Shanghai and Beijing. In Beijing, Made in China in the Grand Hyatt Hotel got the highest rating of 27 for food; in Shanghai, Hanagatami, a Japanese place in the Portman Ritz-Carlton, got the highest rating at 28.

docs.snippet: Contemporary art in China is a man’s world, but these female artists in Beijing are creating some of the most innovative work around.
docs.lead_paragraph: Contemporary art in China is a man’s world, but these female artists in Beijing are creating some of the most innovative work around.

docs.abstract: China continues to block full access to scores of Web pages for thousands of foreign journalists at Olympic Village press center, despite promise of open Internet by International Olympic Committee president Jacques Rogge; blocks to sites such as Amnesty International and newspaper Web sites known for freewheeling political discourse closely resemble restrictions imposed on Chinese citizens; China propaganda authorities call such sites harmful to national security and maintain reporters' coverage of Olympic Games should not be affected; photo (L)

headline.main: Beijing Games Denying Media Full Use of Web

docs.snippet: The International Olympic Committee reportedly agreed to some limitations the government demanded.
docs.lead_paragraph: The International Olympic Committee failed to press China to allow fully unfettered access to the Internet for the thousands of journalists arriving here to cover the Olympics, despite promising repeatedly that the foreign news media could ''report freely'' during the Games, Olympic officials acknowledged Wednesday. Since the Olympic Village press center opened Friday, reporters have been unable to access scores of Web pages -- among them those that discuss Tibetan issues, Taiwanese independence, the violent crackdown on the protests in Tiananmen Square and the Web sites of Amnesty International, the BBC's Chinese-language news, Radio Free Asia and several Hong Kong newspapers known for their freewheeling political discourse.

docs.abstract: China's environmental regulators unveil stricter emergency pollution controls for Olympic Games; measures would close more factories and expand traffic restrictions if air quality fails to meet approved standards once competition begins (M)
docs.snippet: China unveiled stricter emergency pollution controls for the Olympics that would shutter factories and expand traffic rules.

byline.original: By JIM YARDLEY; Huang Yuanxi contributed research

docs.lead_paragraph: China's environmental regulators on Thursday unveiled stricter emergency pollution controls for the Olympic Games that would shutter more factories and expand traffic restrictions if air quality failed to meet approved standards once the competition began next week. The measures, posted on the Web site of the Ministry of Environmental Protection, would be invoked during the Games only in the case of ''extremely unfavorable weather conditions'' -- for example, hot, humid air without wind to disperse pollution.

docs.abstract: Approaching Olympic Games have trained spotlight on China's rights record; conventional wisdom is that China's people have become richer but not much freer in past two decades, and Communist Party has staked its future on their willingness to live with that tradeoff; that view obscures more complex reality: political change, however gradual and inconsistent, has made China significantly more open place for average people than it was generation ago; Chinese people increasingly live where they want to live, they travel abroad in larger numbers and property rights have found broader support in courts; people also enjoy fruits of technological revolution, from cellphones to Internet, and can communicate or find information with ease that has few parallels in authoritarian countries of past; photos (M)

headline.main: Despite Flaws, Rights in China Have Expanded

docs.snippet: Political change in China, however gradual and inconsistent, has made it a significantly more open place for many people than it was a generation ago.

byline.original: By HOWARD W. FRENCH; Li Zhen contributed research from Beijing, and Fan Wenxin and Zhong Zijuan from Shanghai

docs.lead_paragraph: For the past two decades, China's people became richer but not much freer, and the Communist Party has staked its future on their willingness to live with that tradeoff. That, at least, is the conventional wisdom. But as the Olympic Games approach, training a spotlight on China's rights record, that view obscures a more complex reality: political change, however gradual and inconsistent, has made China a significantly more open place for average people than it was a generation ago.

docs.abstract: Beijing Olympics were supposed to be moment China opened itself almost fully to foreign media; government in 2007 changed its policy and allowed foreign journalists to travel much more freely; Pres Hu Jintao and other officials have become more receptive to interviews, but government has also reverted to familiar defensive crouch in year that has included violent Tibetan protests and devastating earthquake (M)

headline.main: China's Leader Meets the Press, but Only on His Country's Very Narrow Terms

docs.snippet: President Hu Jintao’s press conference on Friday was the first he has held in Beijing in the six years he has served as China’s top leader.
docs.lead_paragraph: President Hu Jintao held a press conference on Friday with foreign reporters, starting the one-week countdown to the opening ceremony of the Olympics here. This, in itself, was news. Mr. Hu has had fleeting interactions with the foreign press when he travels abroad, but has not held a press conference in Beijing in the nearly six years he has served as China's top leader. But in a week when the Chinese government was widely criticized for trying to censor Internet access for journalists at the Olympic Village, Mr. Hu's briefing was less an uninhibited interview than another example of the government's awkward efforts to fulfill Olympic promises of opening up to the news media -- but not too much.

docs.abstract: Organizers of Beijing Olympics agree to discuss making available certain Internet sites that have been blocked for journalists working at Olympic Village (M)

headline.main: Olympic Organizers to Weigh Unblocking More Web Sites

docs.snippet: A handful of sites were opened to reporters on Friday and a working group is now examining other sites, one by one, to determine if other sites should be available.
docs.lead_paragraph: Organizers of the Beijing Olympics have agreed to discuss making available certain Internet sites that have been blocked for journalists working at the Olympic Village, an official from the International Olympic Committee said Saturday. A handful of sites, including Amnesty International and the BBC's Chinese language edition, were opened to reporters on Friday. A working group of Olympic organizers and I.O.C. officials is now examining other sites, one by one, to determine if other sites should be available.

docs.snippet: China's favored gymnast hopes to bring back a gold this summer.
docs.lead_paragraph: China's favored gymnast hopes to bring back a gold this summer.
